III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4124 Communication
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a written policy regarding
Description communication that ensures that a child is able to
communicate with family and friends in a manner appropriate
to the child's functioning and consistent with the child's
treatment plan and security level.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has not been allowed to have contact with her attorney or
probation officer for months.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 03/13/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A identified Staff 1 as the
main, assigned staff to assist youth with making outgoing phone
calls. She stated her concern was not with Staff 1 but other staff
that do not respond appropriately to her requests to make
outgoing phone calls. Youth A was not able to give specific
examples of staff or specific instances but referenced general
responses she received when she asked to make phone calls to
her mother, probation officer or her attorney. Youth A recalled
being told that moment was not a good time to attempt to make a
phone call as a common response. She was not able to recall the
last time she attempted a phone call. Youth A stated she has
been able make outgoing phone calls to everyone she mentioned
but expressed concern she has not been able to do so in a timely
manner. Youth A confirmed she has received incoming phone
calls from her mother, and her probation officer has visited her
each month during her placement at the facility. Youth A also
reported having contact with her attorney before and during court
hearings in which she has participated virtually.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 04/18/2025 over the phone. She
confirmed that she was a staff at the facility responsible for
helping youth make outgoing phone calls. Staff 1 recalled Youth
A approaching her personally at times to ask about making a
phone call, and in addition recalled instances, without specific
detail, of other staff telling her Youth A wanted to make a phone
call. Staff 1 recalled some of Youth A’s outgoing phone call
attempts. She remarked Youth A’s mother did not often answer
the phone or return phone calls to Youth A. She remarked Youth
A had been able to make successful outgoing phone calls to her
probation officer. Staff 1 recalled the facility did not have the
contact information for Youth A’s attorney for some period of time
2

but they were able to obtain that from the probation officer, and
since that time Youth A had attempted phone calls with her
attorney. Staff 1 did not believe Youth A asked to make phone
calls any more frequently than any other youth in the facility. Staff
1 stated youth are not allowed to attempt to make phone calls
when they are engaged in another activity, such as during school
hours or after school when they are participating in individual or
group treatment, so there are times when opportunities are not
frequent to make outgoing phone calls to individuals who are likely
to answer the phone only during business hours. Staff 1 believed
youth’s requests to make phone calls are generally met within the
next day of that request.
Youth A’s Probation Officer was interviewed on 04/18/2025 over
the phone. She recalled receiving phone calls from Youth A since
she was assigned to Youth A’s case while placed at the
facility. She expressed no concern over the facility’s handling of
outgoing phone calls. Probation Officer also stated she had been
able to make monthly face-to-face contact with Youth A at the
facility and Youth A never expressed concern to her over inability
to make outgoing phone calls. Probation Officer recalled
providing the contact information for Youth A’s attorney to the
facility, but was not aware of any attempt by Youth A to
communicate with her attorney.
Attempts were made to interview Youth A’s attorney on
04/14/2025 and 04/18/2025 and no return contact was made.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Client Rights” was provided and
reviewed. This policy stated, “Clients are permitted to
make and receive personal telephone calls to approved
contact persons.”
• Documentation of Youth A’s visitation contacts from the
facility since late December 2024 was provided and
reviewed. Youth A was provided the opportunity to attempt
phone contact with her mother on a weekly basis. Youth
A’s probation officer made face-to-face visits to the facility
in January 2025.
• Email communication between facility staff and Youth A’s
probation officer was provided. This referenced attempts
made by the facility in February 2025 to collaborate with the
probation officer and also requests made to gain the
contact information of Youth A’s attorney.
3

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed Youth A was afforded the
opportunity to have phone contact with approved individuals.
Technical assistance:
The facility was offered technical assistance to ensure that all
necessary contact information for members of a youth’s case is
provided to them at the time of placement.
Consultation:
The facility was offered consultation to update procedures
regarding specific times of day for outgoing phone calls and
clearing inform youth that calls will not be made during scheduled
activities unless in case of an emergency.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
